revised_title: Bacterial and Viral Pathogenicity: Iron Uptake and Adaptation in Host Tissues
tldr: This article discusses how bacteria adapt and multiply in host tissues by developing mechanisms to acquire iron, a crucial nutrient for their growth. Bacteria produce siderophores, which remove iron from iron-binding proteins, and new outer-membrane proteins to help in iron uptake. Additionally, alterations in tRNA molecules occur during iron restriction, which may play a role in cellular regulation and metabolic flexibility.
